Research                                          For program information packets, please click here to contact Joy Scheidell.       SOLVE offers an excellent educational opportunity in Comparative Effectiveness Research: the Comparative Effectiveness Research Training (CERT) Program .       Students can participate in (1) the CERT July Summer Institute and earn a Certificate in Comparative Effectiveness Research ( CERT Certificate Track ) or (2) a 14-month Master’s program to earn a Master of Science in Clinical Investigation concentration in Comparative Effectiveness Research ( CERT Master’s Track ).   Click here for further information about the CERT Program . Comparative Effectiveness and Decision Science | Department of Population Health                            Skip to main content                      Patient Care       Faculty & Staff Directory       Events       Careers       Donate                                                                                                                                                                             Department of Population Health                                                                                  Home   About   Faculty   Divisions   Research   Education   Faculty Affairs   News/Events   Contact                                  Home Divisions Comparative Effectiveness and Decision Science            Print  Email               - A + A                                                                                                                                    Comparative Effectiveness and Decision Science     Director: Scott Braithwaite, MD, MSc   The Division of Comparative Effectiveness and Decision Science bridges the worlds of decision science, cost effectiveness, comparative effectiveness and metrics development. Its investigators perform scientifically rigorous research that informs clinical care and health policy. Through building innovative tools and fostering collaboration, our work empowers the most influential decision makers in the field. The mission of the Division’s work is to maximize your quality of life and how long you live. Its investigators perform scientifically rigorous research that informs clinical care and health policy. Through building innovative tools and fostering collaboration, our work empowers the most influential decision makers in the field. Effectiveness Research Training (CERT) Program                                              Jump to:    Program     Overview   Eligibility   Applications, Tuition, and Fee Schedule   Core Curriculum   Course Schedule   Mentorship   Course Descriptions    Faculty & Staff     CERT Certificate Track   In an effort to improve the CERT Certificate Track’s accessibility, for students with prior research training, we now offer the CERT July Summer Institute , a condensed, intensive training initiative that maintains the rigor and comprehensiveness of our existing comparative effectiveness research training.   As a result of the condensed five week format of the CERT July Summer Institute courses are highly intensive and rigorous. During the CERT July Summer Institute coursework period from July 6th to August 7th, 2015, we are requiring a full-time, 40 hour/week commitment for class attendance. This does not include readings and homework. Thus, students are unable to maintain other professional responsibilities, clinical or otherwise, during this time period.   CERT Certificate Track Summary:   For those who possess an advanced degree (e.g. MPH, MS), but who do not have training in comparative effectiveness research.   Condensed, five week CERT July Summer Institute with in-class courses (July 6th to August 7th, 2015) . Course schedule is found here .   Five core comparative effectiveness research method courses that retain the same content and rigor of our prior training will be taught over the five week period (Semester length courses will no longer be offered for completion of the CERT Certificate Track).   Full-time commitment is required during the CERT July Summer Institute coursework (July 6th to August 7th, 2015).   By the end of the CERT July Summer Institute , each scholar is expected to have written and is encouraged to submit one abstract.   CERT Master’s Degree Track (MSCI-CER)   For students who have received little to no formal training in clinical research, we offer a Master of Science in Clinical Investigation with a concentration in Comparative Effectiveness Research Track (MSCI-CER). The MSCI-CER is completed within 14 months.   CERT Master’s Track (MSCI-CER) Summary:   For those who have received little to no formal training in clinical research and who seek skills needed to become an independent researcher.   CERT Master’s Track Semester-long courses (e.g., in biostatistics, epidemiology) in Fall 2015 and Spring 2016 followed by the 2016 CERT July Summer Institute .   Each scholar is paired with a faculty mentor and will meet biannually with an Executive Committee to monitor their progress towards meeting their research goals.   By graduation, each scholar is expected to have submitted at least one manuscript and one abstract.   Submissions of complete applications are being accepted through March 13, 2015 .   Click here for tuition and fee information.   Return to Top   Eligibility for Application   Applicants to our program must meet at least one of the following requirements:   Be Board Eligible or Certified in a Clinical Specialty   Be currently licensed to practice medicine in New York State   Hold a PhD active in a clinical research related discipline   Hold a Master’s degree in Public Health, Healthcare Business Administration or a related field   Hold a leadership position in the Healthcare, Health Policy or Public Health fields   Return to Top   Applications, Tuition, and Fee Schedule   Applications   CER applications are due March 13, 2015 .   CER Online Application   2014-2015 Tuition Fee Schedule   For questions about the application process or tuition and fees, please contact Program Coordinator, email Joy Scheidell or call her at 646.501.2892.   Return to Top   Core Curriculum   The five curriculum courses include: Decision Analysis, Meta Analyses and Systematic Review, Advanced Methods in Observational Data Analysis (Biostatistics III), Cost Effectiveness Analysis and Decision Aids and Clinical Decision Supports (CER course descriptions can be found below).   The MSCI and additional elective courses include: Clinical Research Methods, Intro to Biostatistics I, Scientific Integrity and the Responsible Conduct of Research (online certificate to be completed before graduation), Advanced Epidemiology, Biostatistics II, Clinical Trial Design, Medical Informatics and Grant Writing, Integrative Seminar, Developing New Drugs, and Biomolecular Medicine.   Formatting Changes in the CER Certificate Program:   Condensed, summer intensive program occurring July- August 2014 .   5 CER core courses will retain the same in content and taught as 1 to 2 week modules only. Semester length courses will no longer be offered for the certificate program.   We are still finalizing the sequence of courses, and expect the schedule to be specified over the next few weeks.   Each course will run 1 to 2 weeks in duration.   Full time commitment is required during the two months of certificate course work.   CER Certificate program cost: : $15,000   Return to Top   Course Schedule   Click here to download the course schedule as a PDF file.   Return to Top   Mentorship   All MSCI-CER Master’s Program students will receive mentorship. Certificate students are not required to receive mentorship for program completion.   The CER training program emphasizes the value of applying classroom learning through an in-depth a mentored research initiative in CER. We have adopted an approach to mentorship in which each scholar will be mentored at multiple levels, as described below. This model reflects the fact that scholars’ needs for mentoring fall in multiple domains, including technical research advice, teaching, professional and personal guidance, sponsorship, role-modeling, career crafting, and socialization into the profession.   Besides present mentorship, each scholar will be matched with a comparative effectiveness focused mentor. Scholars and mentors are expected to meet at least twice a month to discuss research, readings and complementary education. Each scholar will also be expected to meet quarterly with Dr. Scott Braithwaite to review progress, coordinate advice and provide constructive feedback.   Return to Top   CER Course Descriptions   View detailed CER course descriptions   Return to Top   Faculty & Staff   Program Director      Maria Khan, PhD , is an Associate Professor in the Section on Value and Effectiveness in the Division of Comparative Effectiveness and Decision Science. She completed her doctoral degree in infectious disease epidemiology at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 2007 and her post-doctoral fellowship in the NIDA-funded Behavioral Sciences Training Program at the National Development and Research Institutes (NDRI) in 2009.   Dr. Khan studies social determinants of sexually transmitted infections including HIV (STI/HIV) in vulnerable populations. She has considerable expertise in the study of criminal justice system involvement and STI/HIV risk, including measurement of the effects of incarceration on sexual risk behavior, changes in sexual networks, and STI/HIV. She is PI on a longitudinal cohort study conducted among African American men released from prison to measure the influence of the dissolution of committed relationships that occurs during incarceration on mental health status and HIV-related sexual risk behaviors and drug use during community re-entry. In a second line of research conducted, Dr. Khan uses the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health (Add Health) to examine the influence of adverse events in childhood and adolescence on adulthood incarceration and STI/HIV risk. Dr. Khan also examines social determinants of STI/HIV in global settings. Her most recent international project focused on measuring mobility and STI/HIV among pregnant women in a semi-urban area located at the epicenter of the 2010 earthquake.     CERT Executive Committee          R. Scott Braithwaite MD, MSc , is Associate Professor and Chief of the Section on Value and Effectiveness (SOLVE) at New York University School of Medicine and President Elect of the Society of Medical Decision Making. Dr. Braithwaite earned his medical degree from the State University of New York at Stonybrook in 1993. Following medical school, he went on to complete a fellowship in clinical decision making at Tufts University in 2001, and since then has completed his master’s degree in science from the University of Pittsburgh.   Dr. Braithwaite is a recipient of a prestigious Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Faculty Scholar award. He is an accomplished investigator in the field of decision science, quality and cost-effectiveness with an outstanding record of funding from the NIH and other extramural sources. As chief of SOLVE, he is dedicated to advancing a program of rigorous, policy-relevant research to optimize quality and value in healthcare, incorporating methods of decision science, comparative effectiveness and cost effectiveness. In addition to his focus on improving care for chronic illness domestically, he also continues his important international work on HIV treatment strategies in developing countries.    Marc Gourevitch, MD, MPH , is Professor and founding Chair of the Department of Population Health at the NYU School of Medicine. Dr. Gourevitch leads initiatives to improve population health through interventions in health care delivery, bridging multiple departments and several of NYU’s schools. He is co-Director of the Community Engagement and Population Health Research Core of the Clinical and Translational Science Institute that bridges NYU with New York City’s municipal hospital system, the Health and Hospitals Corporation. His research interests center on health service utilization and clinical epidemiology among drug users and other underserved populations; integrating pharmacologic treatments for opioid and alcohol dependence into primary care; and strategies for bridging academic research with applied challenges faced by health care delivery systems and public sector initiatives. From 2004-2012, Dr. Gourevitch served as Director of NYU’s Division of General Internal Medicine. Dr. Gourevitch holds joint appointments in the Departments of Medicine and of Psychiatry as well as at NYU’s Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service.            Michael Pillinger, MD , is Associate Professor of Medicine and Biochemistry and Molecular Biochemistry at NYU School of Medicine. He is also Director of TREC (Translational Research, Education and Careers--the educational arm of the NYU Clinical and Translational Science Institute), and Director of the NYU Masters of Science in Clinical Investigation--Translational Research Track. Dr. Pillinger is a rheumatologist who directs the NYU Rheumatology Fellowship Training Program and is the Chief of Rheumatology at the NY Harbor Health Care System NY Campus. His research interests include gout, inflammation and synovial biology.            Mark Schwartz, MD , is Associate Professor of Medicine at New York University (NYU) School of Medicine. After studying medicine at Cornell University and training in internal medicine at NYU, Dr. Schwartz was awarded a Bowen-Brooks Fellowship by the New York Academy of Medicine to study medical education innovation in Israel and Holland, and then completed a General Internal Medicine Fellowship at Duke University. At NYU he was selected as a Robert Wood Johnson Generalist Physician Faculty Scholar. He has been a primary care general internist in urban underserved settings for 25 years.   Dr. Schwartz has studied primary care workforce issues since the 1980’s and recently completed a national study of influences on student interest in internal medicine. His health services research focuses on how primary care workplace characteristics impact physician stress and burnout and, subsequently, quality of care and medical errors. He currently leads a Veterans Administration study of how panel management and clinical microsystem educational interventions for health professionals improve patient outcomes.   Since 1995, Dr. Schwartz has led NYU’s General Internal Medicine Fellowship Program and established its Master’s of Science in Medical Education program. He was founding Director of the educational core (Translational Research Education and Careers program) for NYU’s Clinical Translational Science Institute (CTSI). He directed NYU’s NIH Clinical Research Training Program and led its Master’s of Science in Clinical Investigation program. The Association of Clinical Research Training awarded him its Distinguished Research Educator award in 2008. Funded via the National Science Foundation, Dr. Schwartz leads an international Working Group of biologists, physicians, and educators to develop and test model curricula to infuse evolutionary biology into medical education.   In 2009-2010, he was a Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Health Policy Fellow in Washington, DC, where he served on the professional staff of the Health Subcommittee of the Committee on Ways and Means in the US House of Representatives. Dr. Schwartz worked on negotiating, drafting, and passing the Affordable Care Act health care reform legislation along with various Medicare payment policy issues.         Heather Taffet Gold, PhD , is Associate Professor in the Section on Value and Effectiveness and Assistant Director of Health Disparities and Outcomes Research in the NYU Cancer Institute. She received her Ph.D. in Health Services Research and Policy from the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry. Dr. Gold holds a B.S. degree in biology from the University of California at San Diego and earned an M.A. degree in public policy studies from the University of Chicago, after which she was a health policy analyst working on major policy issues in Washington, DC.   Dr. Gold is a health services researcher whose work focuses on identifying and evaluating the implications of socioeconomic, racial/ethnic, and geographic disparities in cancer care and on the adoption and diffusion of new medical technology. She seeks to determine how differences in care affect health and economic outcomes in order to provide the basis for new health care policies that encourage appropriate use of medical technology in ways that save lives and efficiently and fairly allocate available resources.      Program Coordinator     Joy Scheidell is Program Coordinator for SOLVE’s MSCI-CER and CER Certification Programs.
